overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 87 new PRs (38 merged), 11 new issues, and 65 active contributors.

topIssues.title: op-batcher: stay in sync with op-node rollup config
topIssues.author: joshklop
topIssues.body:
Upon startup, the op-batcher fetches the rollup config from the op-node over RPC. It never fetches the rollup config after that.

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/40554025301e5adde90191adba6ad432e185fa50/op-batcher/batcher/service.go#L238-L253

This is problematic during hard forks when the system deposit transaction format changes: an outdated rollup config will result in an error from which the batcher cannot recover without restarting.
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/40554025301e5adde90191adba6ad432e185fa50/op-batcher/batcher/driver.go#L310
```
failed to parse L1 info deposit tx from L2 block: data is unexpected length: 178
```

The op-batcher should stay in sync with the op-node's rollup config.

One solution is to fetch the rollup config if the above error is hit. An alternative is to for the batcher to restart itself automatically.

topIssues.title: [op-acceptance-tests] Report unused tests
topIssues.author: scharissis
topIssues.body:
Discover and report unused acceptance tests.
All tests should be within a gate and run.

topIssues.title: op-chain-ops: broken dependency github.com/tyler-smith/go-bip39
topIssues.author: seungjulee
topIssues.body:
<!--
Need help?
Refer to our contributing guidelines for additional information about making a good issue:
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Bug Description**
https://github.com/tyler-smith/go-bip39 is no longer hosted on GitHub, and thus is no longer available as a dependency. 

However, it is still referred on the code. 

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/develop/op-chain-ops/devkeys/hd.go#L8
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/blob/develop/go.mod#L62


It's still in proxy.golang.org, but when you don't use GOPROXY, `go mod tidy` breaks.

https://proxy.golang.org/github.com/tyler-smith/go-bip39/@v/v1.1.0.info


**Steps to Reproduce**

On a clean clone, 
```
export GOPROXY=off
go mod tidy
```

I think this command made me notice this broken dependency. 
```
 go clean -cache -modcache -testcache && go mod download
```
**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->

**Environment Information:**
go version go1.24.3 darwin/arm64

**Configurations:**
<!--
Command line flags or environment variables you're using.
-->

**Logs:**
```
        remote: Repository not found.
        fatal: repository 'https://github.com/tyler-smith/go-bip39/' not found

```

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

---

‚ö†Ô∏è **Notice:** Issues that do not include the following sections will be subject to closure:
- Bug Description
- Steps to Reproduce
- Environment Information

Please ensure all required sections are filled out accurately to expedite the debugging process and improve issue resolution efficiency.

topPRs.title: feat: introduce fee splitter for revenue share
topPRs.author: 0xDiscotech
topPRs.body:
**Description**

Introduce the `FeeSplitter` predeploy as part of a new revenue-sharing feature. The goal is to make revenue sharing simpler and more modular, with configurable values and automated handling where possible.

Includes supporting contracts like `SuperchainRevSharesCalculator`, `L1Withdrawer`, and `FeesDepositor`, which act as periphery components of the system and cover the first expected use case.

This is opt-in, but will be enabled by default on fresh chains at genesis. Operators must set a chain fees recipient address on L2 for splits to work.

`FeeVaults` were updated to be more flexible with setters, while keeping backwards compatibility.

**Tests**

* All new contracts are fully unit tested.
* Genesis logic has dedicated tests, and there ar integration tests covering the full main flow.
* Invariant tests added using Foundry as fuzzer.

**Additional context**

* [specs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/specs/pull/782)
* [design-docs](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/328)

**Metadata**

When the `FeesDepositor` contract for OP‚Äôs L1 fees is deployed, it should be linked [here](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17505)

‚ö†Ô∏è  **Disclaimer**: We made minimal changes to the Go files to get the checks passing and did so carefully. Go isn‚Äôt our primary expertise, so we‚Äôd appreciate extra attention from Go reviewers on these edits.

topPRs.title: op-dispute-mon: node endpoint error metrics
topPRs.author: pauldowman
topPRs.body:
This PR adds the following prometheus metrics to dispute-mon:

* Gauge of total number of endpoints that returned an error (other than not found) during the last update cycle - note this is the number of rpcs that had at least 1 failure, so if the same rpc gives an error on 10 games that still counts as 1.
* Gauge of total number of failures (other than not found) in the last update cycle. This counts each error from an rpc as a new event even if the rpc is the same (so one rpc giving 10 errors sets this to 10).
* Gauge of the total number of games where some nodes reported not found and others had the block in the last update cycle.
* Gauge of the total number of games where some nodes reported the output root as safe and others as unsafe in the last update cycle
* Gauge of the total number of games where nodes returned different expected output roots in the last update cycle

Reviewers might want to look at each commit separately, there's one for each metric.

Closes #11020

completedItems.title: op-node: remove dead code
challenger: Stop kona-host using color in logs
completedItems.body:
**Description**

Somewhere along the line Kona-host started outputting colour codes in logs which caused cannon to think they were binary and log them as hex blobs.  Set NO_COLOR=1 to tell it to stop that.

topContributors.summary: ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.

opgitgovernance: This month, opgitgovernance focused on automated maintenance and improving test stability across repositories. They opened pull requests in `optimism` to address test flakiness (#18106, #18107) and submitted automated code generation updates to `superchain-registry` (#1137, #1138). Additionally, they generated automated metrics reports by opening and closing two issues in the `docs` repository (#1825, #1826), with their code changes primarily touching tests and configuration files.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.
pauldowman: Focused on bug fixing this month, pushing a significant commit that modified 20 files with over 2000 lines of code changes.

MrLightspeed: Focused on new feature development this month, opening three pull requests (#1234, #1235, #1236) in `ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io` to add a Creator Coin on Base. While this work remains unmerged, it represents a significant effort involving over 48,000 lines of additions across 833 files. The changes show a primary focus on feature work and modifications to configuration files.

Doryu001: This month's activity consisted of a small code maintenance task in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They opened a pull request (#18108) to remove a redundant path join in a helper script. This change involved a single commit modifying one file (+2/-3 lines).
